A Siberian tiger's back has the highest contrast between its stripes, followed by a zebra's legs with black and white stripes, and lastly a giraffe's neck with a more subtle pattern of light and dark patches.
Leopards have high contrast spots on their backs, antelopes have moderate contrast on their legs, and hippos have low contrast on their backs.

Pandas have a very high contrast between their black and white fur. Kangaroos have a lighter belly compared to their darker back. Sika deer have a reddish-brown coat with less contrast than the other two.

Antelopes often have distinct, high-contrast markings on their heads. Sika deer have a reddish-brown coat with some contrast, while brown bears typically have a uniformly dark brown coat with low contrast.

A bee has high contrast with its black and yellow stripes, a Bichon Frise is mostly white with some color variation, and a killer whale is primarily black and white but with less stark contrast than a bee.
A skunk has the highest contrast with its black and white stripes, followed by the Sika deer with its spotted coat, and lastly the Russian Blue cat with its muted grey-blue fur.

A mantis often has very high contrast between its green body and bright colors, a Dalmatian has black spots on a white coat, and a giraffe has a pattern of light and dark brown. This makes the mantis the highest contrast, followed by the Dalmatian, and then the giraffe.

Swans are known for their stark white and black coloration, creating the highest contrast. Shiba Inus have a reddish-brown coat with some white markings, offering moderate contrast. Siberian Huskies have a predominantly grey and white coat, resulting in lower contrast compared to the other two.
Cheetahs have the highest contrast with their black spots on a tan coat. Samoyeds are white, offering moderate contrast. Cows are typically black and white or brown, resulting in the lowest contrast.

A line segment, when translated, will intersect its original position exactly once. Imagine sliding a ruler along a surface; it crosses its original position only at one point.
A line segment translated at an angle will intersect the original segment at two points.
A horizontal line segment translated at a 30-degree angle will never intersect with its original position. The translation moves it parallel to its original orientation.
A vertical line segment, when translated along a direction at a 72-degree angle, will never intersect its original position. The translation will create a parallel line.

A slanted line segment translated vertically will intersect the original line segment an infinite number of times. Imagine sliding a slanted ruler up a wall - it will cross its original position infinitely many times.
A translation shifts a shape without rotating or resizing it.  Since the line segment is only moved horizontally, it will never intersect its original position.
A line segment translated perpendicular to itself will never intersect its original position. The translation moves it parallel, not across, its original path.
Translating a line segment vertically creates a parallel line. Connecting the original and translated segments forms a trapezoid, a quadrilateral with one pair of parallel sides.
Translating a line segment downward and connecting it to the original creates two parallel sides and two perpendicular sides, forming a rectangle.
Shifting a line segment to the upper left and connecting it to the original creates a trapezoid, a quadrilateral with at least one pair of parallel sides.
Translating a line segment to the left creates a parallel line. Connecting the original and translated segments forms a parallelogram.
Translating a line segment upward and connecting it to the original creates a four-sided shape with one pair of parallel sides, which is the definition of a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment downward creates a parallel line. Connecting the original and translated segments forms a parallelogram.
Translating the line segment to the left and connecting it to the original creates two line segments that form an angle, resulting in a triangle.
Shifting a line segment up and to the left by its own length creates a parallelogram. The opposite sides will be parallel and equal in length.
Translating a line segment upward and then to the right creates a new line segment parallel to the original. Connecting the endpoints forms a parallelogram.
Translating a line segment upward and then to the left creates a second line segment parallel to the original. Connecting the endpoints forms a parallelogram.
Rotating the arrow 180 degrees clockwise will reverse its direction, making the arrowhead point south.
Rotating the arrow 180 degrees clockwise will reverse its direction, making it point West.
Rotating a south-pointing arrow 90 degrees clockwise results in it pointing east.
A 270-degree counterclockwise rotation from pointing right results in pointing downward.
Rotating a leftward ray 90 degrees clockwise results in an upward direction.
Rotating a downward ray 90 degrees counterclockwise results in a horizontal ray pointing to the right.
Rotating a ray 180 degrees clockwise reverses its direction. If it initially pointed right, it will point left after the rotation.
Rotating a leftward ray 90 degrees counterclockwise results in a downward direction.
Rotating a ray 270 degrees clockwise around its endpoint results in a ray that is perpendicular to the original ray.
Rotating a line 45 degrees around a point on the line will bring it back to its original position, making it coincident with the original line.
Rotating a line segment 180 degrees around one endpoint will cause it to overlap perfectly with its original position.
Compressing the left half towards the right will shift the midpoint of the entire line segment to the right.
Compressing the right half of the line segment to the left will shift the overall midpoint of the line segment towards the left.
Compressing both sides of the line segment towards the center will maintain the midpoint's position. It's like squeezing the middle of a rope - the center point stays the same.
Compressing a line segment upward maintains the relative position of its midpoint.
Compressing a ray horizontally makes it steeper, thus more vertical.
Compressing a line segment from both ends towards the center maintains the position of the midpoint.
Stretching the left half to the left will shift the entire midpoint of the line segment towards the left.
Stretching the right half of the line segment to the right will shift the overall midpoint of the line segment to the right.
Stretching both sides of the line segment equally will not change the position of the midpoint. The midpoint remains the same distance from both ends.
When a line segment is folded at its midpoint, the two ends meet at a single point.
Folding a line segment at its midpoint and unfolding it creates an angle where the two halves meet.

When you fold a line segment to form an isosceles right triangle, the hypotenuse is the original line segment.  The two legs of an isosceles right triangle are congruent and have a length of √2/2 times the length of the hypotenuse.
When you fold a line segment to form an equilateral triangle, you divide the original line segment into two equal parts, which become the sides of the triangle.

When you fold a line segment to form an equilateral triangle, the original line segment becomes the base of the triangle.  The height of an equilateral triangle bisects the base, creating two 30-60-90 right triangles. In a 30-60-90 triangle, the hypotenuse (the original line segment) is twice the length of the shorter leg (1/2 the base). The longer leg (a side of the equilateral triangle) is √3 times the length of the shorter leg. Therefore, each side of the equilateral triangle is √3/2 the length of the original line segment.
When you fold a line segment to form a square, you are essentially dividing the original line segment into four equal parts, making each side of the square half the length of the original segment.
When you fold a line segment to form three sides of a square, you are essentially dividing the original line segment into two equal parts. Each of these parts then becomes a side of the square.

When you fold a line segment to form two sides of a square, the line segment becomes the diagonal of the square. The diagonal of a square is √2 times the length of a side. Therefore, each side of the square is 1/√2 or √2/2 times the length of the original line segment.  This simplifies to 1/2 * √2, which is equivalent to 1/√2. To get rid of the radical in the denominator, we multiply both numerator and denominator by √2, resulting in (√2)/(2).
Rotating a right-angled triangle 180 degrees around its right angle vertex will result in the hypotenuse pointing in the same direction as it originally did.

Rotating a shape 180 degrees around a vertex will result in the shape facing the opposite direction, but the relative positions of its sides remain the same. Therefore, the hypotenuse will still be in the same direction relative to the triangle.
Rotating a right-angled triangle 90 degrees counterclockwise around its right angle will result in the hypotenuse remaining in the same direction. The sides simply swap positions.
